title: ITTelecom Companies Growing Enterprise Social Software Centric
text:
(MENAFN Press) The report titled showcases an in-depth analysis of the market in terms of market size deployment model and end-user. This report also forecasts the growth numbers till 2019 (on a YoY basis) and hence suggests the Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) for the estimated period. 
Business Expansion mode of IT & Telecom companies driving the Usage of ESS 
Most of the IT & Telecom companies across the globe are in the expansion mode and the employees of these companies are require to co-ordinate in a much organized way. To facilitate this many of the IT & Telecom companies are embracing Enterprise Social Software. This industry has emerged as the highest contributor of revenue to the entire ESS market among the industry verticals and the rate of adoption is expected to grow further due to higher inclination of most of the IT Telecom and Software companies towards Social media tools as a part of their SMAC strategy.
Due to the on-going outsourcing strategy of businesses IT & Telecom companies are bound to closely co-ordinate with many of their partners located at the other side of the globe. Similarly many of the employees work overseas at the client place and need to remain in touch with their native counterpart. All these would require to have a co-ordination tool. So Enterprise Social Software not only plays the role of a project management tool but also allows the management to convey their decisions or change of policies swiftly without the need for traditional communication like the email.
 As of now the rate of adoption is growing fast among the European and Asia-Pacific regions’ IT & Telecom companies. The reason behind this being that the IT & Telecom industry as a whole is seeing phenomenal growth in these two regions and the employees here are required to frequently communicate with their counterparts and most of these IT companies are stressing more on improving their operational efficiency and reduce delay in processes.
